elements.content: Three new bioactive silver­(I) coordination polymers formulated as [Ag2(μ2-PTA)­(μ3-PTA)­(μ2-pga)­(H2O)] n ·6H2O (1), [Ag2(μ2-PTA)­(μ3-PTA)(Hpmal)2] n ·2H2O (2), and [Ag­(μ3-PTA) (Hdmga)] n (3) were self-assembled from Ag2O, 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane (PTA), and a substituted dicarboxylic acid (3-phenylglutaric acid (H2pga), phenylmalonic acid (H2pmal), or 3,3-dimethylglutaric acid (H2dmga)) as an ancillary ligand. Compounds 1–3 were fully characterized by IR and NMR spectroscopy, ESI-MS(±), elemental analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction, revealing that their architectural and topological diversity is governed by structural modulation of a dicarboxylate building block. The structures vary from a 1D cyclic chain with the SP 1-periodic net (4,4)­(0,2) topology in 2 to distinct 2D metal–organic layers with the cem-d and hcb topologies in 1 and 3, respectively. In addition, compounds 1–3 exhibit a notable antimicrobial efficiency against a panel of common Gram-negative ( and ) and Gram-positive () bacteria and yeast (). The best normalized minimum inhibitory concentrations (normalized MIC) of 11–23 nmol mL–1 (for bacterial strains) or 68 nmol mL–1 (for a yeast strain) are shown by compound 2, and the eventual structure–bioactivity correlations are discussed.

elements.content:
Three new structurally distinct and bioactive silver­(I) coordination polymers were synthesized, fully characterized, and applied as potent antimicrobial agents.

Introduction

In recent years, different strains of bacteria and fungi that are multiresistant to conventional organic antimicrobials have become a worldwide public health issue, justifying the specific use of more potent, metal-containing topical antimicrobial materials. Given the recognized antimicrobial action of silver ions, various Ag­(I)-based metal–organic frameworks (bioMOFs) or coordination polymers (CPs) have become a particularly promising class of compounds that is well suited for the fabrication of “tailor-made” antimicrobial agents and materials for the use in food packaging, wound dressing, metallodrug development, water treatment, antiseptic formulations, and advanced medical devices. Nevertheless, despite the rising valorization of silver coordination networks as effective antimicrobial agents, their practical application is still limited, mainly due to difficulties in the preparation of light-stable and water-soluble compounds, as well as the unknown mechanism of antimicrobial action. Therefore, there is a demand not only for developing new efficient silver-based antimicrobials but also for gathering information that will fill the gaps in their still-enigmatic antimicrobial mechanisms of action.

Three new structurally distinct and bioactive silver(I) coordination polymers were synthesized, fully characterized, and applied as potent antimicrobial agents.

Introduction

In recent years, different strains of bacteria and fungi that are multiresistant to conventional organic antimicrobials have become a worldwide public health issue, justifying the specific use of more potent, metal-containing topical antimicrobial materials. Given the recognized antimicrobial action of silver ions, various Ag(I)-based metal-organic frameworks (bioMOFs) or coordination polymers (CPs) have become a particularly promising class of compounds that is well suited for the fabrication of "tailor-made" antimicrobial agents and materials for the use in food packaging, wound dressing, metallodrug development, water treatment, antiseptic formulations, and advanced medical devices. Nevertheless, despite the rising valorization of silver coordination networks as effective antimicrobial agents, their practical application is still limited, mainly due to difficulties in the preparation of light-stable and water-soluble compounds, as well as the unknown mechanism of antimicrobial action. Therefore, there is a demand not only for developing new efficient silver-based antimicrobials but also for gathering information that will fill the gaps in their still-enigmatic antimicrobial mechanisms of action.

elements.content: Among many parameters that influence the generation, stability, water solubility, and antimicrobial properties of silver coordination networks, the rational selection of multidentate O-, N-, or P-ligands is the most crucial. In this regard, the mixed-ligand approach for the controlled preparation of “tailor-made” coordination compounds using a water-soluble N,P-aminophosphine, 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane (PTA), along with different O-type ancillary ligands constitutes a particularly promising research direction. Our prior studies suggest that a key for the rational design of polycarboxylate tailored Ag-PTA networks lies in the nature of 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane. We found that the soft (P) and hard (N) character of donor atoms within the adamantane cage can not only stabilize silver centers and increase the solubility of obtained networks but also favor the formation of principal [Ag­(PTA)2]+ secondary building blocks. This brings a certain level of predictability into the synthetic procedure, enabling the direct investigation of the effect of various polycarboxylate ligands on the structure formation and antimicrobial activity of Ag-PTA based coordination polymers. Moreover, a combination of this information with the moderate stability of Ag-PTA-carboxylate networks may lead to the development of materials that show a long-term antibacterial and antifungal effect and are capable of efficiently inhibiting pathogen growth via time-dependent ion releasing processes. Therefore, the Ag-PTA-carboxylate networks can be considered as promising Ag+ ion releasing antimicrobial materials with potential uses in sanitizing mixtures, first aid ointments, and wound dressing formulations, on account of their wide spectrum of antimicrobial action, polymeric architectures, moderate aqueous solubility, and appropriate coordination environments.

elements.content: Thus, as a further continuation of our research in this field, we have chosen three dicarboxylic acids with either aromatic or aliphatic substituents, namely 3-phenylglutaric acid (H2pga), phenylmalonic acid (H2pmal), and 3,3-dimethylglutaric acid (H2dmga), in order to explore their application as ancillary building blocks in the self-assembly of Ag-PTA coordination polymers. Hence, we report herein the synthesis, characterization, structural features, and antimicrobial properties of three novel Ag-PTA coordination polymers: [Ag2(μ2-PTA)­(μ3-PTA)­(μ2-pga)­(H2O)] n ·6H2O (1), [Ag2(μ2-PTA)­(μ3-PTA)(Hpmal)2] n ·2H2O (2), and [Ag­(μ3-PTA)(Hdmga)] n (3).

elements.content: All synthetic work was performed in air. 1,3,5-Triaza-7-phosphaadamantane (PTA) was prepared by a published method developed by Daigle and co-workers. All other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The Microanalytical Service of the Instituto Superior Técnico carried out the C, N, and H elemental analyses. Infrared (IR) spectra were measured in the 4000–400 cm–1 range on a BIO-RAD FTS 3000MX or a Bruker IFS 1113v instrument using KBr disks (abbreviations: vs, very strong; s, strong; m, medium; w, weak; br broad; sh, shoulder). 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker 300 and 500 AMX spectrometers at ambient temperature. ESI-MS(±) spectra were run on a LCQ Fleet mass spectrometer with an ESI source (Thermo Scientific), using ∼10–3 M solutions of 1–3 in H2O/MeOH.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All synthetic work was performed in air. 1,3,5-Triaza-7-phosphaadamantane (PTA) was prepared by a published method developed by Daigle and co-workers. All other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The Microanalytical Service of the Instituto Superior Técnico carried out the C, N, and H elemental analyses. Infrared (IR) spectra were measured in the 4000-400 cm-1 range on a BIO-RAD FTS 3000MX or a Bruker IFS 1113v instrument using KBr disks (abbreviations: vs, very strong; s, strong; m, medium; w, weak; br broad; sh, shoulder). 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker 300 and 500 AMX spectrometers at ambient temperature. ESI-MS(±) spectra were run on a LCQ Fleet mass spectrometer with an ESI source (Thermo Scientific), using ~10-3 M solutions of 1-3 in H2O/MeOH.

elements.content: Ag2O (0.1 mmol, 23 mg) and H2pga (0.25 mmol, 52 mg) were dissolved in a mixed solvent (7 mL of MeOH/3 mL of H2O) and then combined with PTA (0.2 mmol, 31 mg). The obtained cloudy mixture was stirred for 2 h at room temperature, resulting in the formation of a white-pink precipitate. This precipitate was dissolved by dropwise addition of an aqueous 1 M NH4OH solution (until pH 8–9; ∼0.5 mL) and then filtered off. The transparent filtrate was left at room temperature for crystallization, giving light pink crystals (including those suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction) in 1 week: ∼50% yield based on Ag2O. Compound 1 is slightly soluble in H2O (S 25 °C ≈ 1.5 mg mL–1). Anal. Calcd for C23H50Ag2N6O12P2 (1·H2O, MW 880.4): C, 31.38; N, 9.55; H, 5.52. Found: C, 31.26; N, 9.65; H, 5.22. elements.content: The X-ray diffraction data of 1–3 were collected using a Bruker AXS-KAPPA APEX II diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Data were collected using ω scans of 0.5° per frame, and a full sphere of data was obtained. Cell parameters were retrieved using Bruker SMART software and refined using Bruker SAINT on all the observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. Structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS 97 program and refined with SHELXL 97. Calculations were performed with the WinGX System, Version 1.80.03. The hydrogen atoms were inserted at geometrically calculated positions and included in the refinement using the riding-model approximation; U iso(H) values were defined as 1.2U eq of the parent carbon atoms for methylene residues. The structure refinement details and crystal data for 1–3 are summarized in .

X-ray Crystallography

The X-ray diffraction data of 1-3 were collected using a Bruker AXS-KAPPA APEX II diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Data were collected using ω scans of 0.5° per frame, and a full sphere of data was obtained. Cell parameters were retrieved using Bruker SMART software and refined using Bruker SAINT on all the observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. Structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS 97 program and refined with SHELXL 97. Calculations were performed with the WinGX System, Version 1.80.03. The hydrogen atoms were inserted at geometrically calculated positions and included in the refinement using the riding-model approximation; U iso(H) values were defined as 1.2U eq of the parent carbon atoms for methylene residues. The structure refinement details and crystal data for 1-3 are summarized in .

The antimicrobial activity of 1–3 and AgNO3 as a reference was evaluated by the method of serial dilutions using Antibiotic Broth ((g L–1 (H2O)): Dextrose 1.0; K2HPO4 3.68; beef extract 1.5; peptone 5.0; KH2PO4 1.32; NaCl 3.5; yeast extract 1.5), according to Grove and Randall. The PCM 2054 (=ATCC 25923) and PCM 2057 (=ATCC 25922) strains were obtained from the Polish Collection of Microorganisms of the Institute of Immunology and Experimental Therapy in Wrocław, Poland, whereas and were isolated from clinical samples in the Department of Veterinary Microbiology, University of Environmental and Life Sciences, Wrocław, Poland. The last two strains were identified using conventional methods and the miniaturized identification systems API 20 NE and ID 32 C (bioMérieux), respectively. An overnight culture of each strain was diluted 1:1000 in Antibiotic Broth (AB). To a series of tubes containing appropriate amounts of AB, aqueous solutions of 1–3 were added to give 0.9 mL. In each well, 0.1 mL of the microbial suspension was pipetted. The following concentrations of tested compounds were obtained (μg mL–1): 60, 50, 40, 30, 20, 10, 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, and 1. In addition, the antimicrobial properties of PTA were examined using the same method, showing a lack of antimicrobial activity at a concentration lower than or equal to 600 μg mL–1 (higher concentrations were not tested for solubility reasons). Broth sterility control and (for each strain) growth controls were included. The tubes were incubated at 37 °C for 24 h. Each antimicrobial assay was performed in duplicate. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC, μg mL–1) was defined as the lowest concentration of the compound that completely inhibited the growth of bacteria or fungi in both repetitions. The turbidity of well contents was controlled using a DEN-1B densitometer (Biosan, Latvia). For the sake of comparison, the MIC values were normalized for the molar content of silver in 1–3 and are also given on a nmol mL–1 scale ().

Antibacterial and Antifungal Activity Studies

The antimicrobial activity of 1-3 and AgNO3 as a reference was evaluated by the method of serial dilutions using Antibiotic Broth ((g L-1 (H2O)): Dextrose 1.0; K2HPO4 3.68; beef extract 1.5; peptone 5.0; KH2PO4 1.32; NaCl 3.5; yeast extract 1.5), according to Grove and Randall. The  PCM 2054 (=ATCC 25923) and  PCM 2057 (=ATCC 25922) strains were obtained from the Polish Collection of Microorganisms of the Institute of Immunology and Experimental Therapy in Wrocław, Poland, whereas  and  were isolated from clinical samples in the Department of Veterinary Microbiology, University of Environmental and Life Sciences, Wrocław, Poland. The last two strains were identified using conventional methods and the miniaturized identification systems API 20 NE and ID 32 C (bioMérieux), respectively. An overnight culture of each strain was diluted 1:1000 in Antibiotic Broth (AB). To a series of tubes containing appropriate amounts of AB, aqueous solutions of 1-3 were added to give 0.9 mL. In each well, 0.1 mL of the microbial suspension was pipetted. The following concentrations of tested compounds were obtained (μg mL-1): 60, 50, 40, 30, 20, 10, 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, and 1. In addition, the antimicrobial properties of PTA were examined using the same method, showing a lack of antimicrobial activity at a concentration lower than or equal to 600 μg mL-1 (higher concentrations were not tested for solubility reasons). Broth sterility control and (for each strain) growth controls were included. The tubes were incubated at 37 °C for 24 h. Each antimicrobial assay was performed in duplicate. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC, μg mL-1) was defined as the lowest concentration of the compound that completely inhibited the growth of bacteria or fungi in both repetitions. The turbidity of well contents was controlled using a DEN-1B densitometer (Biosan, Latvia). For the sake of comparison, the MIC values were normalized for the molar content of silver in 1-3 and are also given on a nmol mL-1 scale ().

These values were normalized for the molar content of silver in each compound.

The reaction of Ag2O with PTA and a dicarboxylic acid (i.e., 3-phenylglutaric acid (H2pga), phenylmalonic acid (H2pmal), or 3,3-dimethylglutaric acid (H2dmga)) in H2O/MeOH solution, followed by further alkalization with aqueous NH3, resulted in the self-assembly formation of three novel structurally distinct Ag-PTA coordination polymers: namely [Ag2(μ2-PTA)­(μ3-PTA)­(μ2-pga)­(H2O)] n ·6H2O (1), [Ag2(μ2-PTA)­(μ3-PTA)(Hpmal)2] n ·2H2O (2), and [Ag­(μ3-PTA)­(Hdmga)] n ·(3) (). These products were isolated as air-stable microcrystalline solids, and their formulations were confirmed by IR and NMR spectroscopy, ESI-MS(±), elemental analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. All of the obtained compounds feature water solubility (S 25 °C ≈ 1.0–3.5 mg mL–1). It should be noted that the use of phenylsuccinic and dimethymalonic acids as ancillary ligands has also been attempted in the Ag/PTA synthetic system, but the obtained products were not suitable for a single-crystal X-ray diffraction study.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

The reaction of Ag2O with PTA and a dicarboxylic acid (i.e., 3-phenylglutaric acid (H2pga), phenylmalonic acid (H2pmal), or 3,3-dimethylglutaric acid (H2dmga)) in H2O/MeOH solution, followed by further alkalization with aqueous NH3, resulted in the self-assembly formation of three novel structurally distinct Ag-PTA coordination polymers: namely [Ag2(μ2-PTA)(μ3-PTA)(μ2-pga)(H2O)] n ⋅6H2O (1), [Ag2(μ2-PTA)(μ3-PTA)(Hpmal)2] n ⋅2H2O (2), and [Ag(μ3-PTA)(Hdmga)] n ⋅(3) (). These products were isolated as air-stable microcrystalline solids, and their formulations were confirmed by IR and NMR spectroscopy, ESI-MS(±), elemental analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. All of the obtained compounds feature water solubility (S 25°C ~ 1.0-3.5 mg mL-1). It should be noted that the use of phenylsuccinic and dimethymalonic acids as ancillary ligands has also been attempted in the Ag/PTA synthetic system, but the obtained products were not suitable for a single-crystal X-ray diffraction study.

elements.content: The IR spectra of all compounds show the characteristic vibrations of the PTA and carboxylate ligands. The intense bands at 1598–1537 and 1404–1383 cm–1 were assigned to asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups, respectively. The frequency difference (Δν) between the νas(COO) and νs(COO) bands can indicate the coordination mode of the carboxylate groups in compounds 1–3. The large Δνas‑s values of 241, 215, and 236 cm–1 for 1–3, respectively, suggest the coordination of the COO groups in a bis­(monodentate) (1), monodentate (2 and 3), or “pseudo-bridging” fashion (1 and 3); in the last case the uncoordinated O carboxylate atoms of μ2-pga2– and Hpmal– ligands are involved in the formation of hydrogen bonds. The IR spectra also reveal a set of bands in the 1200–900 cm–1 region due to the characteristic ν­(C–X) (X = P, N) vibrations of the PTA ligand.

The frequency difference (Δν) between the νas(COO) and νs(COO) bands can indicate the coordination mode of the carboxylate groups in compounds 1-3. The large Δνas-s values of 241, 215, and 236 cm-1 for 1-3, respectively, suggest the coordination of the COO groups in a bis(monodentate) (1), monodentate (2 and 3), or "pseudo-bridging" fashion (1 and 3); in the last case the uncoordinated O carboxylate atoms of μ2-pga2- and Hpmal- ligands are involved in the formation of hydrogen bonds. The IR spectra also reveal a set of bands in the 1200-900 cm-1 region due to the characteristic ν(C-X) (X = P, N) vibrations of the PTA ligand.

elements.content: The ESI-MS­(+) spectra of all compounds dominate by an intense [Ag­(PTA)2]+ signal at m/z 421 with a characteristic isotopic distribution pattern. Heavier fragments of lower intensity are detected at m/z 735 (in 1), 706 (in 2), and 689 (in 3), which are attributed to the [Ag2(PTA)2(Hpga)]+, [Ag2(PTA)2(Hmal)]+, and [Ag2(PTA)2(Hdmga)]+ moieties, respectively. Additional fragments [Ag3(PTA)3(Hpga)]+ (in 1), [Ag2(PTA)2(Hmal)]+ (in 2), and [Ag2(PTA)2(Hdmga)]+ (in 3) are observed at m/z 998, 970, and 952, respectively; all feature a characteristic isotopic distribution. In the negative ESI-MS(−) mode, the data are less informative, revealing signals at m/z 622 and 423 in compounds 2 and 3, respectively; these correspond to the [Ag­(PTA)­(dmga)]− and [Ag­(PTA)­(Hpmal)2]− moieties. The obtained mass spectrometry results are in good agreement with those reported for other [Ag­(PTA)­(carboxylate)] n compounds. In all cases, the ESI-MS­(+) plots of Ag-PTA-carboxylate derivatives reveal the presence of two main cationic species identified as [Ag­(PTA)2]+ and [Ag2(PTA)2(carboxylate)]+, thus supporting the relative stability of coordination polymers in solution. Moreover, collision-induced dissociation methods (CID-MS) can provide detailed information about the specific stability of these particular ions in solution, which is a reflection of the binding properties of P-, N-, and O-donor ligands within the coordination environment of Ag centers. In fact, the CID-MS n experiment on [Ag­(PTA)2]+ displays its progressive fragmentation with the elimination of N-coordinated PTA in the MS2 spectra and successive cleavage of the adamantane cage without breaking of the Ag–P bond. Hence, the fragmentation of [Ag2(PTA)2(carboxylate)]+ ions primarily involve a loss of the PTA molecule and further elimination of the [Ag­(carboxylate)] moieties, giving rise to the most stable [Ag­(PTA)2]+ species.

elements.content: The 1H NMR spectra of 1–3 exhibit a typical set of resonances for both the P–CH2–N and N–CH2–N types of protons of the PTA ligand; these are shifted downfield in comparison to those of noncoordinated PTA. In addition, in all compounds the methylene proton signals of the pga2–, Hmal–, and Hdmga– ligands are observed in the δ 3.52–1.04 region, being shifted in comparison to those of “free” dicarboxylic acids. Typical resonances due to the aromatic substituent in compounds 1 and 2 occur at δ 7.36–7.2 and 7.40–7.30, respectively. The 31P­{1H} NMR spectra of 1–3 show the characteristic broad singlets in the range from δ −78.6 to −80.1, which are typical for coordinated PTA blocks.

elements.content: In summary, the investigation of solution behavior of 1–3 by NMR spectroscopy and ESI-MS methods not only supports the coordination of PTA and dicarboxylate ligands to the metal center but also evidences the preservation of the coordination environment of silver­(I) atoms in the obtained compounds upon their dissolution in aqueous medium. Although the above analyses do not confirm the maintenance of the extended polymeric architectures of Ag-PTA-carboxylate networks in solution, 1–3 most probably exist in aqueous medium as oligomeric species that vary in size.
elements.clean_text: In summary, the investigation of solution behavior of 1-3 by NMR spectroscopy and ESI-MS methods not only supports the coordination of PTA and dicarboxylate ligands to the metal center but also evidences the preservation of the coordination environment of silver(I) atoms in the obtained compounds upon their dissolution in aqueous medium. Although the above analyses do not confirm the maintenance of the extended polymeric architectures of Ag-PTA-carboxylate networks in solution, 1-3 most probably exist in aqueous medium as oligomeric species that vary in size.

elements.content: Compound 1 reveals a 2D metal–organic layer structure (). Its asymmetric unit consists of two distinct Ag1 and Ag2 atoms, two different μ2-PTA and μ3-PTA spacers, one μ2-pga2– linker, one terminal H2O ligand, and two water molecules of crystallization. As presented in a, the Ag1 and Ag2 atoms are both four-coordinate and display different {AgN2OP} and {AgNO2P} donor sets, respectively. The Ag1 atoms are surrounded by two N atoms and one P atom (Ag1–N11 2.429(4), Ag1–N21 2.379(5), Ag1–P1 2.441(4) Å) from three neighboring PTA ligands and one O atom (Ag1–O1 2.393(1) Å) from the μ2-pga2– linker, forming a geometry intermediate between the seesaw and trigonal pyramidal with a τ4 parameter of 0.84. The coordination sphere of the Ag2 centers is completed by one O atom (Ag2–O3 2.221(4) Å) from the μ2-pga2– ligand, one P and one N atom (Ag2–P2 2.324(1), Ag2–N22 2.477(5) Å) from two different PTA spacers, and one O atom (Ag2–O40 2.635(5) Å) from the water ligand, forming a distorted-seesaw geometry (τ4 = 0.70). The adjacent Ag1 and Ag2 atoms are interlinked via an unusual combination of μ2- and μ3-PTA spacers into 1D ladderlike chain motifs composed of cyclic trisilver­(I) {Ag3(PTA)3}3+ units (b). These Ag-PTA motifs are further joined together by the μ2-pga2– pillars in which the carboxylate groups act in monodentate modes, giving rise to a ladder-pillared 2D metal–organic layer. Multiple intermolecular hydrogen bonds involving water molecules of crystallization lead to the 2D → 3D extension of the structure, resulting in a 3D supramolecular framework.
elements.clean_text:
Structural and Topological Description of Compounds 1-3 

Crystal Structure of [Ag2(μ2-PTA)(μ3-PTA)(μ2-pga)(H2O)] n ⋅6H2O (1)

Compound 1 reveals a 2D metal-organic layer structure (). Its asymmetric unit consists of two distinct Ag1 and Ag2 atoms, two different μ2-PTA and μ3-PTA spacers, one μ2-pga2- linker, one terminal H2O ligand, and two water molecules of crystallization. As presented in a, the Ag1 and Ag2 atoms are both four-coordinate and display different {AgN2OP} and {AgNO2P} donor sets, respectively. The Ag1 atoms are surrounded by two N atoms and one P atom (Ag1-N11 2.429(4), Ag1-N21 2.379(5), Ag1-P1 2.441(4) Å) from three neighboring PTA ligands and one O atom (Ag1-O1 2.393(1) Å) from the μ2-pga2- linker, forming a geometry intermediate between the seesaw and trigonal pyramidal with a τ4 parameter of 0.84. The coordination sphere of the Ag2 centers is completed by one O atom (Ag2-O3 2.221(4) Å) from the μ2-pga2- ligand, one P and one N atom (Ag2-P2 2.324(1), Ag2-N22 2.477(5) Å) from two different PTA spacers, and one O atom (Ag2-O40 2.635(5) Å) from the water ligand, forming a distorted-seesaw geometry (τ4 = 0.70). The adjacent Ag1 and Ag2 atoms are interlinked via an unusual combination of μ2- and μ3-PTA spacers into 1D ladderlike chain motifs composed of cyclic trisilver(I) {Ag3(PTA)3}3+ units (b). These Ag-PTA motifs are further joined together by the μ2-pga2- pillars in which the carboxylate groups act in monodentate modes, giving rise to a ladder-pillared 2D metal-organic layer. Multiple intermolecular hydrogen bonds involving water molecules of crystallization lead to the 2D → 3D extension of the structure, resulting in a 3D supramolecular framework.

elements.content: For the sake of topological classification of the 2D metal–organic network in 1, we performed its analysis following the concept of the simplified underlying net. Such a net (c) was generated by omitting terminal H2O ligands and reducing all of the bridging organic moieties to their centroids, resulting in a binodal 3,4-connected layer. It is composed of the 4-connected Ag1 and topologically equivalent 3-connected Ag2 and μ3-PTA nodes, as well as the 2-connected μ2-pga2– and μ2-PTA linkers. Topological analysis of this net reveals a rare cem-d (Shubnikov plane net (33.42)/dual) topology with the point symbol of (53)2(54.82), wherein the (53) and (54.82) notations are those of the Ag2/μ3-PTA and Ag1 nodes, respectively.

It is composed of the 4-connected Ag1 and topologically equivalent 3-connected Ag2 and μ3-PTA nodes, as well as the 2-connected μ2-pga2- and μ2-PTA linkers. Topological analysis of this net reveals a rare cem-d (Shubnikov plane net (33.42)/dual) topology with the point symbol of (53)2(54.82), wherein the (53) and (54.82) notations are those of the Ag2/μ3-PTA and Ag1 nodes, respectively.

elements.content: Compound 2 features infinite 1D cyclic metal–organic chains built from two symmetry-nonequivalent Ag1 and Ag2 atoms, two monodentate Hpmal– ligands, two different μ2- and μ3-PTA blocks, and a pair of H2O molecules of crystallization per asymmetric unit (). The four-coordinate Ag1 atom exhibits a heavily distorted {AgN2OP} seesaw geometry (τ4 = 0.80) (a), formed by one O atom from the Hpmal– ligand and one P atom and two N atoms from three different PTA moieties. The Ag–N, Ag–P, and Ag–O bond distances range from 2.379 to 2.441 Å. The Ag2 center displays a distorted {AgNOP} trigonal planar geometry defined by one O atom from the second Hpmal– ligand and one P atom and one N atom from the μ2- and μ3-PTA blocks, respectively (Ag2–O5 2.242(2), Ag2–P2 2.334(7), Ag2–N3 2.365(1) Å). All bond distances in 2 are comparable to values observed in 1 and in other silver coordination networks with similar coordination environments. As in 1, two kinds of PTA blocks act as bidentate and tridentate spacers organizing the silver centers into 12-membered rings that give rise to infinite 1D cyclic chains (b). In contrast to the case for 1, these chain motifs in 2 are only stabilized by the ancillary Hpmal– moieties and are not extended further by coordination interactions. However, a number of hydrogen bonds between the crystallization water molecules and 1D chains lead to the 1D → 3D extension of the structure, thus generating a 3D supramolecular framework.

All bond distances in 2 are comparable to values observed in 1 and in other silver coordination networks with similar coordination environments. elements.content: Although compound 3 also has a 2D metal–organic network (), it is different from that of 1. The asymmetric unit of 3 comprises one silver­(I) atom, one μ3-PTA spacer, and one terminal Hdmga– ligand. The four-coordinate Ag1 center displays a distorted {AgN2OP} seesaw geometry (τ4 = 0.71), which is occupied by two N atoms and one P atom from three different μ3-PTA blocks and one O atom from the monodentate Hdmga– moiety (Ag1–N1 2.410(3), Ag1–N2 2.710(3), Ag1–P1 2.352(9), Ag1–O1 2.237(2) Å) (a). In contrast to the case for 1 and 2, the PTA blocks act herein only as tridentate spacers that give rise to the symmetric [Ag3(PTA)3]3+ cyclic motifs with an Ag···Ag separation of 6.697 Å (b). These cyclic motifs are held together and extend in two dimensions by the same alternately N,N,P-coordinated μ3-PTA blocks to generate a regular 2D honeycomb-like metal–organic network, which is additionally stabilized by the terminal Hdmga– ligands. Topological analysis of the simplified underlying net of 3 (c) discloses a uninodal 3-connected 2D layer with the hcb (Shubnikov hexagonal plane net/(6,3)) topology and a point symbol of (63). This layer is driven by the 3-connected topologically equivalent Ag1 and μ3-PTA nodes.

elements.content: An analysis of crystal structures demonstrates that the nature of the dicarboxylate ligands is a fundamental factor that causes the structural dissimilarities in the obtained Ag-PTA coordination polymers. The effect of the substituent modulation in the dicarboxylate anions under the fixed synthetic reaction conditions is reflected by the distinct dimensionalities, topologies, and, to some extent, coordination modes of PTA spacers. In fact, the use of dicarboxylate blocks with an aromatic substituent (3-phenylglutaric and phenylmalonic acids) resulted in the generation of similar 1D Ag-PTA motifs in 1 and 2; these are composed of the trisilver­(I) {Ag3(PTA)3}3+ units with the alternating μ2- and μ3-coordination modes of PTA. Given an increased length of the backbone chain in H2pga in comparison with that in H2pmal, a μ2-coordination mode of 3-phenylglutarate can be realized in 1, thus leading to an extension of the 1D Ag-PTA motifs into a 2D layer. In contrast, a shorter phenylmalonate moiety acts as a terminal ligand that only stabilizes the 1D Ag-PTA chains. In 1 and 2, phenyldicarboxylate ligands are alternately positioned below and above the PTA moieties, causing a partial blocking of available coordination sites. Most likely, this forces the coordination inversion and favors the formation of the very unusual mixed bidentate N,P- and tridentate N,N,P-coordination modes of the PTA spacer. This assumption is supported by observing a completely different coordination behavior of PTA ligand in 3. A regular 2D honeycomb-like network of 3 is exclusively assembled from the N,N,P-connected aminophosphine ligands, whereas the aliphatic 3,3-dimethyloglutarate moieties act as terminal ligands and are located entirely in voids of adjacent Ag-PTA layers. This indicates that the methyl substituents of Hdmga– are small enough so that their steric hindrance does not affect the coordination preference of the PTA moieties.
elements.clean_text:
Influence of Substituted Dicarboxylate Ligands on the Structural Diversity of Ag-PTA Networks

An analysis of crystal structures demonstrates that the nature of the dicarboxylate ligands is a fundamental factor that causes the structural dissimilarities in the obtained Ag-PTA coordination polymers. The effect of the substituent modulation in the dicarboxylate anions under the fixed synthetic reaction conditions is reflected by the distinct dimensionalities, topologies, and, to some extent, coordination modes of PTA spacers. In fact, the use of dicarboxylate blocks with an aromatic substituent (3-phenylglutaric and phenylmalonic acids) resulted in the generation of similar 1D Ag-PTA motifs in 1 and 2; these are composed of the trisilver(I) {Ag3(PTA)3}3+ units with the alternating μ2- and μ3-coordination modes of PTA. Given an increased length of the backbone chain in H2pga in comparison with that in H2pmal, a μ2-coordination mode of 3-phenylglutarate can be realized in 1, thus leading to an extension of the 1D Ag-PTA motifs into a 2D layer. In contrast, a shorter phenylmalonate moiety acts as a terminal ligand that only stabilizes the 1D Ag-PTA chains. In 1 and 2, phenyldicarboxylate ligands are alternately positioned below and above the PTA moieties, causing a partial blocking of available coordination sites. Most likely, this forces the coordination inversion and favors the formation of the very unusual mixed bidentate N,P- and tridentate N,N,P-coordination modes of the PTA spacer. This assumption is supported by observing a completely different coordination behavior of PTA ligand in 3. A regular 2D honeycomb-like network of 3 is exclusively assembled from the N,N,P-connected aminophosphine ligands, whereas the aliphatic 3,3-dimethyloglutarate moieties act as terminal ligands and are located entirely in voids of adjacent Ag-PTA layers. This indicates that the methyl substituents of Hdmga- are small enough so that their steric hindrance does not affect the coordination preference of the PTA moieties.

elements.content: These observations suggest that a careful selection of auxiliary carboxylate ligands can impose a certain coordination preference and provide a pathway for the controlled assembly of PTA building blocks with silver­(I) nodes. Since the number of the Ag-PTA based networks is limited mostly due to the coordination difficulties in inducing a mode other than the P-coordination of PTA ligand, the obtained compounds 1–3 widen the family of silver-PTA coordination polymers and contribute toward the development of a predictable self-assembly synthetic protocol for such compounds.

elements.content: As a continuation of our efforts in the search for structure–bioactivity relationships and the establishment of some factors that enhance the antimicrobial activity of Ag-PTA derivatives, we studied the antimicrobial properties of compounds 1–3 ().
elements.clean_text:
Antibacterial and Antifungal Properties of 1-3 

As a continuation of our efforts in the search for structure-bioactivity relationships and the establishment of some factors that enhance the antimicrobial activity of Ag-PTA derivatives, we studied the antimicrobial properties of compounds 1-3 ().

elements.content: The antimicrobial efficiency of 1–3 was evaluated in vitro in terms of their minimal inhibitory concentrations (MIC; μg mL–1), which were normalized for the molar content of silver in each compound, resulting in normalized MIC (nmol mL–1). The compounds were tested against common human and animal pathogen species such as , , and bacteria as well as yeast. The lowest normalized MIC values of 11–68 nmol mL–1 were achieved for 2, which are 3–5 times lower than the 53–236 nmol mL–1 observed for AgNO3 as a reference antimicrobial agent. Compounds 1 and 3 exhibit antimicrobial activities somewhat inferior to that of 2, but these are still superior in comparison with silver­(I) nitrate (). A similar antimicrobial activity trend was observed when the data of 1–3 were compared against those of another common reference salt, silver­(I) acetate. As presented in , among the tested compounds, 2 exhibits the most notable activity, resulting in a decrease in the growth of the (normalized MIC 11 nmol mL–1), (normalized MIC 11 nmol mL–1), and (normalized MIC 68 nmol mL–1) strains. In fact, 2 can be used in 2- to 7-fold lower concentrations than those of silver­(I) acetate to achieve the same level of antimicrobial efficacy. Although compounds 1 and 3 are less active than 2, they also show an activity higher than that of silver­(I) acetate, with the normalized MIC values being up to 4-fold inferior to those of the silver salt.

The lowest normalized MIC values of 11-68 nmol mL-1 were achieved for 2, which are 3-5 times lower than the 53-236 nmol mL-1 observed for AgNO3 as a reference antimicrobial agent. Compounds 1 and 3 exhibit antimicrobial activities somewhat inferior to that of 2, but these are still superior in comparison with silver(I) nitrate (). A similar antimicrobial activity trend was observed when the data of 1-3 were compared against those of another common reference salt, silver(I) acetate. As presented in , among the tested compounds, 2 exhibits the most notable activity, resulting in a decrease in the growth of the  (normalized MIC 11 nmol mL-1),  (normalized MIC 11 nmol mL-1), and  (normalized MIC 68 nmol mL-1) strains. In fact, 2 can be used in 2- to 7-fold lower concentrations than those of silver(I) acetate to achieve the same level of antimicrobial efficacy. Although compounds 1 and 3 are less active than 2, they also show an activity higher than that of silver(I) acetate, with the normalized MIC values being up to 4-fold inferior to those of the silver salt.

elements.content: An overview of the obtained experimental data suggests that the differences in antimicrobial efficiency of 1–3 can potentially correlate with their distinct dimensionality and diverse metal–organic network architectures, as well as changes in the coordination environment of silver atoms and nature of the surrounding ligands. In particular, the highest activity observed for 2 can be related to the presence of only terminal monodentate carboxylate ligand and an overall one-dimensional structure that may disaggregate more easily. The lowest activity against tested bacteria and fungi was observed for 1. We note that this compound has the greatest steric bulkiness around the silver atoms due to the presence of a long backbone chain and aryl substituent of the pga2– ligand, as well as its bridging nature. It is possible that the introduction of sterically bulky fragments into a coordination sphere of the Ag center can hamper the passage of the compound through an outer membrane, may decrease the concentration of the released Ag+ ions into the cell, and, as a consequence, can significantly reduce the antimicrobial activity. This assumption can be further supported by the previously reported ESI-MS and antimicrobial data for a series of Ag-PTA-carboxylate networks. In fact, prior data on the antimicrobial activity of the Ag-PTA derivatives bearing aliphatic and cyclohexane polycarboxylate blocks reveal a trend wherein the antimicrobial efficiency declines on increasing the chain length or number of COOH substituents in ligand structures, respectively. Thus, it seems that a sterically sealed and bulky coordination sphere of Ag+ ion can hamper an ion releasing process and play a significant role in the antimicrobial behavior of Ag-PTA-carboxylate coordination polymers. However, these observations should be considered rather cautiously before establishing structure–bioactivity relationships on the basis of a larger series of antimicrobial Ag-PTA compounds.

elements.content: In the present study, we have assembled and fully characterized three novel Ag-PTA coordination polymers, showing that the incorporation of different aryl- or alkyl-substituted dicarboxylate building blocks resulted in the generation of structurally and topologically distinct metal–organic networks. These vary from a 1D cyclic chain with the SP 1-periodic net (4,4)­(0,2) topology in 2 to distinct 2D metal–organic layers with the cem-d and hcb topologies in 1 and 3, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In the present study, we have assembled and fully characterized three novel Ag-PTA coordination polymers, showing that the incorporation of different aryl- or alkyl-substituted dicarboxylate building blocks resulted in the generation of structurally and topologically distinct metal-organic networks. These vary from a 1D cyclic chain with the SP 1-periodic net (4,4)(0,2) topology in 2 to distinct 2D metal-organic layers with the cem-d and hcb topologies in 1 and 3, respectively.

elements.content: The structural diversity of 1–3 and dissimilarities in the coordination preference of aminophosphine ligand clearly indicate that the driving role in the self-assembly generation of these compounds is played by the type of substituted dicarboxylic acid used as an ancillary building block. Apart from contributing to a still limited family of coordination polymers containing PTA and derivatives as versatile cagelike aminophosphine blocks, the obtained products 1–3 also display a notable antimicrobial activity against some common strains of bacteria and yeast.
elements.clean_text: The structural diversity of 1-3 and dissimilarities in the coordination preference of aminophosphine ligand clearly indicate that the driving role in the self-assembly generation of these compounds is played by the type of substituted dicarboxylic acid used as an ancillary building block. Apart from contributing to a still limited family of coordination polymers containing PTA and derivatives as versatile cagelike aminophosphine blocks, the obtained products 1-3 also display a notable antimicrobial activity against some common strains of bacteria and yeast.

elements.content: In addition, the current work also provides a promising mixed-ligand synthetic strategy for the self-assembly generation of a wide range of PTA-based coordination polymers. The design of related Ag-PTA compounds derived from other types of polycarboxylate building blocks in order to establish a relationship between the structure and antimicrobial potential is currently in progress. We believe that this research direction may bring to light even more potent antimicrobial Ag-PTA derivatives and materials thereof.

Ag2O (0.1 mmol, 23 mg) and H2pga (0.25 mmol, 52 mg) were dissolved in a mixed solvent (7 mL of MeOH/3 mL of H2O) and then combined with PTA (0.2 mmol, 31 mg). The obtained cloudy mixture was stirred for 2 h at room temperature, resulting in the formation of a white-pink precipitate. Compound 3 was synthesized by following the procedure described for 1 but using H2dmga (0.25 mmol, 40 mg) instead of H2pga. Compound 3 is soluble in H2O (S 25°C ~ 3.5 mg mL-1).
